In_Teper vs. Reginain (195) A. C 480 at 489, it was held that circumstantial evidence on which
a case depends must satisfy three tests.

column2: The circumstances from which an inference of guilt is sought to be drawn must be
Those circumstances should be a definite tendency, unerringly pointing towards
The circumstances taken cumulatively, should from a chain so complete that there
is no escape from the conclusion that within all human probability the crime was
committed by the accused and no one else.
